SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES,
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Craburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name ____________________________
Present Address ____________________________
Pioneer Address ____________________________
Year you came to Saskatchewan ________

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? (3 or more—about 12 near neighbors)

How many of these were bachelor's homes? (8 of the 12 above)

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? (as often as necessary for work, or borrowing and every Sunday—wanted someone to come)

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? (yes and we only visited during fall games etc., and in the winter parties & suppers)

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? (most done without invitations but married home made special invited occasions)

What time of the day did you go—in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? (in the summer or the evening or at meal time—everyone was there except special occasions)

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? (you never were let go if you happened to be around meal time)

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) (potluck was a common saying or welcome to what we got)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? (American and coffee—English and tea—never saw liquor for years)

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? (no everyone was always welcome—we had no children except two families)

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? (yes if anyone had a misfortune or sick or a big job like log building)

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. (an English family of children—a big log house—they had a fire 1907, put up the shell in two groups in two days also put in some shop—nigger got thrown from house took off his cap—later running cement for mudhouse)

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. (not many home dances until homes got larger 1914 and later schools were then getting built—parties with program Committee songs recitations—plays—debate—mock trials—mock weddings—and contests—programs divided district each put on a nights entertainment)

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. (the ones I judge the best no after 1914 more dances or card parties)

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, —every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? (we usually took invitations in advance—we selected the best suitable homes—every year was open and welcome but some home too small or too far away—no need a regularly elected Committee to arrange)
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pionios, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

9. When was your first community hall built? What material was it made of? How large was it? Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.) For local district things we used the school. But for Chatsworth or big things they went to the hall in town.

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? How were babies and small children provided for? How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Was there card playing for a prize? What dances were popular? Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. Organizations and Meetings:

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? The Valley Progress Committee.

Give the date and reason for being organized.

1907 we started to organize the school district and built the school in 1910.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes.

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

1915. Big thrive & Juniper

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

They finally backed a move to organize a Coop Store.

When was it organized? About 6 years ago.

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services. They are quite active in sending young students to take courses and helps to different organizations. Helps pool committees. Co-ops, etc.

Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

We are only 6 miles from the town of Saskatoon and many of the undertakings there, we contribute help if we had church organization and helped with the co-op store. We also had a very active agricultural fair. We helped with a community hall memorial cairn skating rink.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money? canvass by subscription.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

In a hall in town

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Remember Bracken giving a good address on land culture about 1910. Held in mission hall. We had many minor talks with lantern slides etc.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Twice. Give dates if possible. 1909.

Who provided the lantern and the slides? A neighbor who had been in Yukon. He borrowed the lantern from a minister and got some slides to help out.

What were the slides about? The gold rush and the north country. Some missionary slides.

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? We had swings + letters at school marbles ball our school was near a slough and rafts and wet clothes were common.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? The most of the girls could do anything the boys tried. But one of them is in China as a missionary.

33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

A young English man dressed as a lady was a scream! An Indian chief was very good also & funny. The young lady from Chicago a teacher was so captivated she took pictures all afternoon and finally returned to our valley and took one of the teachers for a husband.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc., Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

Our picnics at first were like a big family gathering but gradually attendance increased until they became more of a sporting day. We had attractions, a walking race, obstacle race, relay race on horseback. When cars started to come, we had car driving races, cigarette races, needle thread races. We were then about 1930 when the whole school went to a resort 15 miles away for a whole day outing, new to picnics.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

1907 everybody had a good time and helped make it a good time for everyone else. 1912 cars were very popular from distance and they came to be entertained. 1930 no one bothered. 1938 - on big sport and go long distance for big advertised commercial sports.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

In the early days football was our game and the older men came out also the women came and visited and hollered. Then we started tennis for grown ups. Also croquet. Then we started baseball and hockey in the winter with snow skating.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? 1907 How long did it continue? Several years

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

Now has a curling rink and skating arena.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? 

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

We have a man in our vicinity who has a wonderful collection of stones and curios, several hundred and is delighted if anyone visits his collection.
